text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Eva L Mitchell (Mrs. J.H.)

Present Address: Weyburn, Sask.

Pioneer Address: Cherokee, Iowa

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Please fill in name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: Eva L Mitchell

Present Address: Weyburn, Sask.

Pioneer Address: ThrOke, ToWA

Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE:

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About 6.
   How many of these were bachelor's homes? None

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?
   I taught school during the week. Sometimes while they were working.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?
   Yes
   What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? After school or on Saturdays & Sundays

5. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?
   Usually stayed for at least one meal

6. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)
   Potluck usually used

7. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?
   Tea cakes were given sometimes

8. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Usually whole family went

9. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, our church was built with a bee by farmers.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.
Usually on account of storms etc., doing neighborly work or buildings

10. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.
    Dances were usually held in school but sometimes in homes; whist drives held also clubs were formed. Dances were attended with music usually one of the neighbors.

    Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.
    Yes, they were.

11. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
    This club formed by young people was held every two weeks, some circles dancing and sometimes also excursion & various projects were held. Others were sent by invitation.
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

The school house was used for community dances, Box socials were held at schools and large amounts were raised and used for school purposes.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

Practically all of our social life was held in school Christmas trees, Sunday School. This was in 1906-07. Picnics were held in groves some 5 miles away.

9. When was your first community hall built? None was built.

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

There was a private hall in town where we could gather.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

Town

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

We still used our school house for gatherings and went to Hall in town for other functions.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Usually

How were babies and small children provided for? The mothers usually packed them upon the old piano or on seats.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

There was a barn at the school.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Whist and Five Hundred.

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular?

Shottische, Polka Waltz's and Square Dances.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

No

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

I can remember no objections. Some people did not attend.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc.)

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

10. What material was it made of?

11. Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? How large was it?

12. To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc?)

13. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

14. How were babies and small children provided for? The mothers usually packed them up on the old fashioned or on seats.

15. How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

16. What card games were popular in the early days?

17. Was there card playing for a prize?

18. What dances were popular? Waltz and square dance.

19. Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

20. Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

Some people did not attend.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc. Many were held, and some were very rough. One especially where the couple did not answer. People were put into the kitchen and the groom shot at the people who had gathered.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

I got married afterward. No social life was curtailed. Married in 1910.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Social Club in 1908

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

For reading and dinner meetings.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Yes.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

About 1914

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Can't remember any farmer's local. There was a women's organization.

How many women belonged? 75

How often did it meet? Every month

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Discussed farmers' problems. Helped in aiding others less fortunate.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Not in our district

When was it organized? Much later

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes

Describe what you remember about chivarees, any incidents connected with them, etc., telling how common they were, where they were held, who came, etc.

14. Give the date and reason for its being organized.

15. What was the name of the first organization or any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged to it?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district?

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who managed (name of president, etc.), whether it included people from one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money? Usually collections and church suppers.

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? At the homes of the members.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Sometimes

Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Mostly special lecturers.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? No Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides? None

What were the slides about? X

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Baseball, Football, Hide-and-seek.

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? London Bridge, Jailing down Old Man Tucker, Playing house - Tagging around the Rozy. They spent a lot of time building houses.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people), whether a social club, etc. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

21. What games did boys play in summer ("mumble type"), ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

22. What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.?  
   Fighting between foxes made snow hockey just with a piece of wood.  
   What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?  
   Authors, checkers, Snap, Crokinole, Carrom.  
   Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.  
   Sometimes families especially in winter.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.  
   Quite a bit of work as boys had to help with chores around the farm and girls helped in the house.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.  
   Used to have circus with gophers etc. as animals. Forts were built.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.  
   June

26. Who organized it?  
   1908

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?  
   Community picnic

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community?  
   1908

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?  
   Ball games, races, no band mostly eating as we had to drive about 15 miles each way.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?  
   General Lunch

31. What did you have to eat and drink?  
   Chicken fried, salad, cake & pies galore also cookies & ice cream. Other meats.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?  
   About 11 o'clock we got there and stayed until late. Usually had 2 meals at least.
22. What winter games were played outside? Fox and hounds, skating, etc.

23. Was there much time for games or was everyone usually busy with work?

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

26. Who organized it? June

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?

28. Was the first picnic held in the community? 1908

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)?

30. What arrangements were made for eating—was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

General Lunch

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

Chickens fried, salad, cake & juice

Pepole also bought from the ice cream.

Other meals

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?

About 11 o'clock we got there and played until late; usually had 2 meals at least
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

This first picnic started about 11 AM. It started to drizzle and rain about 12 PM so we came way back to the church to finish it out. It was very disappointing. However it cleared in afternoon and we had a good time not with standing the poor start.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

School picnics were always held at the end of the school term but community picnics were only once a year. School picnics were not as well attended but they all had a nice time. Not much food or drink.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

Mostly school picnics later on more people attended later as schools began to attend other school picnics.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Baseball, Racing. Mostly young people. But sometimes old men would play the younger.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Baseball

What year? 1910

How long did it continue? For quite a few years.

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Hockey was organized later but not in 1914.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

Built in our back yard and used for hockey.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
31. Describe the features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

32. What kind of church was it? What was the church like?

33. What was the weather like?

34. What was the food like?

35. What was the music like?

36. What was the atmosphere like?

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization, if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

40. When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? 
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?
   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).
   Usually 24th May.

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates. No

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)
   Very few. I don't remember the names I checked. Those that I remember were Melville the Hero - Addison's Essays, The Bible which was my great grandfathers. Last of the Mohicans David Copperfield - Oliver Twist. None of the green gables and others.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Scarcely at all as I guess they didn't like my taste.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.
   Yes.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.
   Yes. It was at our home for about 5 years then one of the South people took it.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? Started 1908

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?
I think it was the books were read at home by the parents.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
   I don't know
40. Then did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Yes.

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? Yes.

Was it responsible for starting the first sports day? Yes.

Then was the first day usually held (what month, or any special day, such as May 1st or July 4th)? Yes.

Were there any from your community who have become members of well-known basketball teams? Yes.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors, if possible, and what kind.) Yes.

What kind of books did you bring? Yes.

What kind of books did you bring? Yes.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Yes.

What kind of books did they bring? Yes.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Yes.

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details. Yes.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? Yes.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Yes.

Give details and dates. Yes.

48. Was there a school library? Yes.

When was it begun? Yes.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home? Yes.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Yes.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes
   When was it started? Who started it?
   Is it still in existence? Yes
   If not, when was it discontinued, and why? It was a public library and they have a very large assortment of books & magazines.

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

The only one which I was associated with was the School Traveling Library which contained about 100 books. All the people in the community used it. Kept at our home for some time. We had books in which I kept a record of books loaned & returned. Wayburn Public Library was established later.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?
   Country Guide, Wayburn Paper
   Hamilton Spectator

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.
   As children grew older added Popular Mechanics, Robbie's Home Journal. Were added Hamilton paper discontinued.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No
   Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?
   None

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. Yes
   No sources of information such as encyclopedias etc. I found it a great hardship.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes

When was it started? When started 1877

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

The only library which I was connected with was the school library which was located in the schoolhouse. We had our home library from which we borrowed books which we returned. They were public property.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to Hamilton County, Wisconsin?

Country Guide, Wayburn Paper

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

As children grew older added Popular Mechanics, Reader's Home Journal. We've added a Hamilton Paper also continued.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? No

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

None

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.

No because of information such as every day paper etc. I found it a great read book.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? None

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Some had pianos.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

Mostly we had lots of singing at the school as I could play the organ.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

Some and quite a bit of Community Singing.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?

Love's Old Sweet Song, Juanita - Britannia God save the King.

in the community?

Man of the Cold Cold Ground, Old Folks at Home God save our King - Old Kentucky Home Carry me back to old Virginia.

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

That none.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? No When was it started? X

Who started it? ✓ How long did it continue? ✓

How many were in it? ✓ Who was bandmaster? ✓

What instruments were included? ✓

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Musical Entertainment.

55. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? None

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Pianos

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the West? Give dates, if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the homes?

61. The "folk music" or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? No

Who started it? 

How many were in it? 

What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances. No.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change? More no.

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Some arrowheads, collections of stones.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain. No

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.? No

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearance.

65. Is music an important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signs, etc.? If so, describe them.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
